;

;丹麦前国防部长和前间谍局长谈到了他们的宽慰在检察官大幅撤销对他们泄露国家机密的刑事指控后。

;

;检察官本周表示，在丹麦最高法院做出一系列裁决，阻止检方秘密进行审判后，他们将撤回案件。

;

;检察官本周表示，他们将撤回案件。 p>;

;该决定结束了;高风险的法律剧;，两名前高级公职人员被指控泄露有关丹麦和美国之间秘密情报伙伴关系的机密信息。

;

;对退伍军人的审判政府部长克劳斯·霍特·弗雷德里克森 (Claus Hjort Frederiksen) 和前间谍头子拉尔斯·芬德森 (Lars Findsen) 定于本月晚些时候上任。两人在被指控犯有叛国罪后均面临监禁。

;
;

;;相关：;;寒冷中：笼罩丹麦的间谍丑闻 - 播客;

;
;

;弗雷德里克森在接受《卫报》采访时表示：“这场噩梦结束了，我感到非常欣慰。对我来说这是非常困难的两年”。他呼吁现在由一个独立法官领导的委员会对“整个过程”进行调查。

;

;芬德森表示，虽然他并不担心如果他的案件上法庭会发生什么，但他说他他“很高兴不必在接下来的三四年内”处理此案。

;

;他说，他对政府和情报监督机构在 2020 年“对敏感问题处理不当感到遗憾”发表了一份针对该国外国情报部门的批评报告。

;

;该报告的发布引发了一系列非同寻常的事件，导致芬德森被停职，并受到侵入性秘密监视并被秘密关押在美国。入狱 70 天。

; ;

;这些刑事案件近年来震撼了丹麦政坛，被视为政府更广泛打击情报界成员泄密行为的一部分。

;

;这两起案件的核心都是指控前官员披露了与丹麦情报机构和美国国家安全局之间一项秘密协议有关的信息，该协议旨在窃听通过丹麦传输互联网流量的光缆。

;

;该交易;首次出现于 2014 年;， ;丹麦记者广泛报道; 2020 年至 2021 年间，检察官试图秘密审理此案。

;

;在审判之前，最高法院做出了一系列判决，裁定需要与 Frederiksen 和 Findsen 共享机密信息听证会应部分公开进行。

;

;周三，检察机关表示，法院做出裁决后，丹麦情报部门通知检察官，追查针对 Frederiksen 和 Frederiksen 的案件“不再安全”芬德森。检察官还撤销了针对一名在该国国内情报机构工作的官员的单独案件。

;

;高级检察官雅各布·伯杰·尼尔森 (Jakob Berger Nielsen) 在评论这一决定时表示：“对于情报部门来说，确保其情报的机密性至关重要。丹麦媒体将案件的撤回解读为总理梅特·弗雷德里克森领导的政府的重大失败，该政府现在面临着政治强烈反对，并呼吁进行独立调查，以调查其对起诉的处理方式。

;

;在 ;社论;中，该报称这些案件“类似于丹麦近代历史上最大的政治/行政丑闻”。

;

;“这些都是案件从各方面来看，唯一真正的问题是丑闻是否是由于极度无能或政治滥用权力造成的，”它说。

;;Félix Verdejo 的最后一场职业比赛于 2020 年 12 月 12 日在拉斯维加斯米高梅大会议中心输给 Masayoshi Nakatani .
;

;拳击神童菲利克斯·维德霍（Félix Verdejo）曾被视为这项运动的下一位伟大的波多黎各明星，周五因残忍杀害其 27 岁怀孕情人而被判两项无期徒刑。 .

;

;一名联邦法官在 2021 年 4 月被杀的凯什拉·罗德里格斯 (Keishla Rodríguez) 的家人发表激动人心的演讲后对 Verdejo 判刑。

;

;Verdejo ;7 月被判犯有绑架致人死亡和致人死亡罪;未出生婴儿的死亡他的律师周五表示，他计划对判决提出上诉。

;

;波多黎各各地的许多人庆祝了此案的结果。

;

;

;在今年早些时候的审判中，Verdejo 的朋友路易斯·安东尼奥·卡迪斯 (Luis Antonio Cádiz) 也被指控参与此案，他表示这位前拳击手曾向罗德里格斯施压，要求他得到堕胎。他还作证说，维德霍杀死罗德里格斯的那天，这位前拳击手对她拳打脚踢，并向她注射了有毒物质，然后他们将她的四肢绑在水泥块上，并在光天化日之下将她从一座繁忙的桥梁上扔进了泻湖。

; ;

;加的斯后来匿名拨打了 911，并提供了罗德里格斯尸体的位置。

;

;尸检发现，罗德里格斯体内含有芬太尼和甲苯噻嗪（一种用于马等动物的镇静剂）。

;

;此案震惊了美国领土，许多人要求更好地保护家庭暴力受害者。

;

;此案震惊了美国领土。 >;

;Verdejo 参加了 2012 年伦敦奥运会，并于当年成为职业拳击手。

;

;他连续赢得了前 23 场比赛，并被多家出版物收录，包括 ;《卫报》;，作为米格尔·库托和菲利克斯·特立尼达的长期潜在继任者;波多黎各人拳击巨星;。

;

;他以 27 胜 2 负的战绩结束了自己的轻量级职业生涯，其中 17 次击倒对手。

;

;据演艺界媒体援引照片报道，演员马修·佩里 (Matthew Perry) 于周六去世，享年 54 岁，周五被埋葬在洛杉矶的一个公墓，葬礼上有 90 年代热门电视情景喜剧《老友记》中的亲戚和演员参加。

; <旁白>;

; ;

;

;曾于 1994 年至 2004 年在《老友记》中饰演俏皮的钱德勒·宾的佩里被发现死于周一，该剧的五名幸存联合主演在联合致辞中向佩里致敬，哀叹他的去世是“难以估量的损失” ”。

;

;包括 TMZ 和《纽约邮报》第六页在内的媒体报道了周五的活动，并发布了出席者的远距离航拍照片。

;

;所有五位《老友记》的联合主演——詹妮弗TMZ 称，安妮斯顿、柯特妮·考克斯、丽莎·库卓、马特·勒布朗和大卫·休默都在场。

;

;第六页称佩里的父亲约翰·贝内特·佩里和他的继父基思·莫里森也在场。

;

;第六页称佩里的父亲约翰·贝内特·佩里和他的继父基思·莫里森也在场。 TMZ 称，总共约有 20 名身着黑衣的人参加并聚集在墓地周围。

;

;Forest Hills 没有回应路透社的确认请求。

;

;《老友记》的联合主演周二发表联合声明，称他们“对这次损失感到非常震惊”，并补充说他们会及时发表更多言论。

;

;佩里的死因和方式是尚未由洛杉矶县法医办公室在完成尸检和毒理学测试后确定。

;

;佩里的去世是在他的回忆录《朋友、情人和可怕的大事》出版一年后，该书记录了他数十年来与处方止痛药和酒精成瘾的斗争。当时，佩里说他已经清醒了大约 18 个月。

;

;同样在周五，以佩里的名义成立了一个基金会，以支持与毒瘾作斗争的人。

;

;马修·佩里 (Matthew Perry)基金会网站称，“将尊重他的遗产，并以他自己的话语和经历为指导，并以他为尽可能多的人的生活带来改变的热情为动力”。

;

;该网站引述了来自佩里说：“当我去世时，我不希望朋友成为第一个提到的事情 - 我希望帮助别人成为第一个提到的事情。”

; Sat, 04 Nov 2023 10:22:02 +0800 Virginia teacher shot by six-year-old can go ahead with $40m lawsuit, judge ruleshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/03/virginia-teacher-gun-student-lawsuit
;;2023-11-04T00:14:34Z;
;
;;橙色校虫前面的黄色犯罪现场胶带库存图片，侧面有红色停止标志。< /div>;

;法官周五裁定，弗吉尼亚州一名被 6 岁学生枪杀的教师可以继续对学校系统提起 4000 万美元的诉讼，指控学校管理人员玩忽职守。

;

;纽波特纽斯巡回法院法官马修·霍夫曼 (Matthew Hoffman) 的意外裁决意味着艾比·兹维尔纳 (Abby Zwerner) 可以获得的不仅仅是工伤赔偿，因为一月份的教室枪击事件造成严重伤害。

;

;纽波特纽斯公众律师学校曾试图阻止诉讼，称茨维尔纳只有资格获得工人赔偿。它提供长达近 10 年的工资和受伤的终身医疗护理。

;
;

;;相关：;;律师称，枪杀弗吉尼亚老师的男孩表现出暴力倾向;

;
;

;霍夫曼不同意学校董事会的观点，得出的结论是 Zwerner 的受伤“并非因工作而造成”，因此“不属于工人赔偿范围的专有条款”。

;

;法官写道：“危险被学生枪击并不是一年级老师的工作所特有的事情。”

;

;Zwerner 的手被子弹击中后住院近两周，并经历了多次手术，胸部。兹维尔纳声称，管理人员忽视了男孩当天持有枪支的多次警告，并且经常驳回对其令人不安的行为的持续担忧。

;

;“这次胜利是我们为艾比伸张正义的道路上的重要垫脚石，”兹维尔纳的律师黛安·托斯卡诺 (Diane Toscano)、杰弗里·布雷特 (Jeffrey Breit) 和凯文·比尼亚赞 (Kevin Biniazan) 在一份声明中表示。

;

;“我们渴望继续追求问责制和公正、公平的复苏，”他们说。 “没有哪个老师会想到会盯着一个六岁学生拿着的枪管。”

;

;学校董事会的律师表示，他们将对周五的决定提出上诉，并在一份声明中表示，他们“完全同意”预计上诉法院会推翻这一判决”。

;

;学校董事会坚持认为，Zwerner 的受伤与她的工作直接相关，因此属于工人赔偿范围。

;

;“就业的实际风险学校董事会律师安妮·莱兰 (Anne Lehran) 在一份声明中表示：“不幸的是，这种情况相当常见，而且这种情况在当今时代只会增加。”

;

;一些法律专家预计，根据弗吉尼亚州异常严格的工人赔偿法，茨维尔纳的诉讼将会失败。这是因为它涵盖了工作场所的袭击和对雇主的疏忽指控。可能在其他州推进的诉讼在英联邦往往会步履维艰。

;

;Zwerner 的律师反驳说，工伤赔偿并不适用，因为一年级教师永远不会预料到会遭到枪击：“这不是一个实际的事件。” ”

;

;Zwerner 诉讼的暂定审判日期定于 2025 年 1 月。

;

;一名一年级学生的课堂枪击事件重新引发了关于枪支暴力的全国对话，并引发了轩然大波。这座位于切萨皮克湾附近的军事造船城市。

;

;1 月初，6 岁的孩子掏出母亲的手枪，向坐在阅读桌旁的茨维尔纳开枪。她把其他学生冲到走廊里，然后倒在学校办公室里。

;

;Zwerner 在 4 月份提起诉讼，指控学校官员无视男孩持有枪支且情绪暴力的多次警告。

; >;

;警方表示枪击事件是故意的。 Zwerner 声称学校官员知道这个男孩在学校和家里“有随机暴力的历史”，包括当他“掐死”他的幼儿园老师时。

;

;弗吉尼亚大学法学教授 JH Verkerke 此前告诉学校美联社报道称，茨维尔纳的律师根据该州的工人赔偿法面临着一场艰苦的斗争。他说，他们需要证明枪击事件与茨维尔纳的工作无关，尽管她是在教室里被枪杀的。

;

;Verkerke 说，他们面临的挑战是“以某种方式证明这是针对个人的”。

;

;霍夫曼在周五的裁决中写道，针对茨维尔纳的枪击事件是“针对个人的”。

;

;他指出，这名男孩从开学到放学前都带着枪。

;

;“直到学生回到[茨维尔纳]的教室后，他才决定开枪一次，击中[茨维尔纳]，”霍夫曼写道。 “他在任何时候都没有用枪支威胁学校的任何其他学生、老师或管理人员。”

;

;茨维尔纳的律师在上个月的一份简报中辩称，男孩的“暴力行为是随机的，针对的是所有人， “无论是在校内还是校外”。

;

;他“声称他对人们‘欺负’他的朋友感到愤怒，这一动机与 [Zwerner] 无关，”她的律师写道，但没有进一步说明详细阐述。 “他的动机是个人的。”

;

;学校董事会不同意，并质疑枪击事件怎么可能与工作无关。

;

;在周五回应法官的决定时，学校表示委员会的律师表示：“很明显，该学生和 Zwerner 女士只是通过师生关系才认识的。”

;

;“为了以‘个人’行动击败工人的排他性' 赔偿法，个人动机本身不得与……就业有关，”他们写道。

;

;工人赔偿法被认为是 20 世纪受伤工人和雇主之间的一项伟大交易，Verkerke说。在大多数情况下，工人失去了起诉的能力，从而保护雇主免受巨额赔偿。但受伤的人更容易获得赔偿——工资损失和医疗保险——而无需证明过错。

;

;

;

;

;

;

;7 月 19 日法庭文件显示，2022 年，全科医生向 Rallah-Baker 的眼科诊所阳光海岸眼科医生发送了电子邮件，其中的评论对原住民造成了“直接、深刻的情感损失”。

;7 月 21 日，即电子邮件发出两天后，Rallah-Baker 向澳大利亚医疗委员会 (Ahpra) 通报了该全科医生的行为，经过调查后，董事会将此事提交给 ACT 民事和行政法庭，因为该法庭有理由相信他的行为构成了职业不当行为。

;

;法庭还考虑了公认的事实，即全科医生也未能维持文化上的尊重。 2022 年 8 月 30 日，全科医生在与 Ahpra 调查员通电话时透露，他拒绝在一名四岁儿童的字迹上写下“CTG”，而该儿童的父亲被认定为原住民。

;

; GP 还对 Ahpra 发表了评论，包括“Ahpra 是盖世太保”。

;

;According to the tribunal's full decision, authored on behalf of the tribunal by senior member Thena Kyprianou, the GP issued an apology to Rallah-Baker and the Ahpra regulatory adviser he made subsequent comments to.

;

;Kyprianou went on, “however, despite these concessions and issued apologies, we are not satisfied that the respondent has gained good insight into his conduct nor that he has shown genuine contrition for it”.

;

;“Apart from the two apologies mentioned above, which were issued through his lawyers, no evidence has been presented to the Tribunal by the respondent supporting that he has taken any steps to gain insight into his conduct or expressing any remorse or contrition for his actions.”

;

;The findings noted a psychiatrist's report dated 30 June 2023 which described the GP “as having a personality with cognitive rigidity and a difficulty in understanding others' emotional responses to his actions”.

;

;The GP resigned in August 2022 and surrendered his registration on 13 September 2023. The tribunal ruled that in addition to a reprimand, it was necessary for the GP to be disqualified from applying for re-registration for 12 months “by way of general deterrence for the profession”.

;

;

;Fuller said with Ahpra reforming the cultural safety of the complaints processes by actively recruiting First Nations staff to “handl[e] complaints involving us … we have a clear path forward to tackling racism in healthcare towards our people”.

;

;Donna Burns, the CEO of the Australian Indigenous Doctors' Association, said one of the best ways to improve cultural safety for First Nations patients was to increase the number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander doctors. “However, we know that the doctors are exposed to these behaviours of racism.”

;

;The latest medical training survey with data from 2022 found 55% of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander trainees had experienced or witnessed bullying, discrimination and harassment, which included racism, compared to 34% of all trainees nationally.

;

;The same survey also found 29% of Indigenous trainees said they were considering leaving medicine, compared to 20% for non-Indigenous graduates.

;

;“Cultural safety is clinical safety,” Burns said. “They can't be decoupled. And holding people to account for culturally safe practice is not only a step towards eliminating racism, but an improvement in clinical care and therefore clinical outcomes.”

;Rallah-Baker told Guardian Australia he hoped speaking out would encourage others. “There is still a lot of fear among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders if they speak up against people in power or institutions in power, they will suffer the consequences.”

; Sat, 04 Nov 2023 04:52:01 +0800 No utopia: experts question Elon Musk’s vision of world without workhttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/03/experts-question-elon-musk-vision-of-ai-world-without-work
;;2023-11-03T17:01:28Z;
;
;;Oscar Wilde
;

;Oscar Wilde thought hard work “the refuge” of those with nothing better to do while he envisaged a society of “cultivated leisure” as machines performed the necessary and unpleasant tasks.

;

;Karl Marx's dream was of state-regulated general production that allowed liberated workers to “hunt in the morning, fish in the afternoon, rear cattle in the evening, criticise after dinner” without the drudgery of being tied to one job.

;

;The 19th-century socialist activist William Morris advocated for more pleasurable work, believing that once the profit motive of the factory had been abolished, less necessary labour would led to a four-hour day.

;

;So ;Elon Musk's suggestion to Rishi Sunak; that society could reach a point where “no job is needed” and “you can do a job if you want a job … but the AI will do everything” revives a debate on the issue of how we work that has long been discussed.

;

;Yet a world without work, experts question, may be more dystopian than utopian.

;

;“This is an old, old story that never actually happens,” said Tom Hodgkinson, co-founder of ;the Idler magazine,; which for three decades has been a platform to examine issues surrounding work and leisure.

;

;“There was a poem in ancient Greece saying, 'Isn't it wonderful that we have invented the watermill so that we no longer have to grind our corn? The women can sit around doing nothing all day from now on.' It's that kind of recurrent idea.

;

;“People like Bertrand Russell were talking about this in the 30s. What would we do without work? One view is people wouldn't know what to do because people are more or less slavish. That they would just sit around watching daytime TV or porn all day.”

;

;In fact, given more free time, such as on furlough during Covid, “they start living better”, Hodgkinson said. “They are starting neighbourhood groups, doing more gardening, doing up the house, spending more time with family, doing creative things, playing music, writing poetry, all the things that are part of what I would call a good life.”

;

;Despite that, he said, studies had shown that paid work was beneficial for mental health, for status and identity.

;

;“I think we need to do some sort of work. We should be moving towards a shorter working week, and more leisure-filled society,” Hodgkinson said, adding that a radical overhaul of our economic and education models would be needed to eliminate work on the scale that Musk predicted.

;

;One; significant body of research in 2019,; led by Brendan Burchell, professor in social sciences and a former president of Magdalene College, Cambridge, established that eight hours of paid employment a week was optimal in terms of benefit in mental health, and that no extra benefit was subsequently accrued.

;

;Setting aside the “awful jobs that really screw you up”, Burchell said, “your average job is good for you” in terms of social interaction, working collectively, giving structure and sense of identity.

;

;A world without work “is a terrible idea of what society would look like for all sorts of reasons, as well as people's mental health”, he said.

;

;The labour market, as a way of distributing money around the economy, would have to be transformed, as would the education system, “to teach people how to fill their days, by writing poetry or going fishing or whatever, instead of going to the factory or the office”, Burchell continued.

;

;Shifting to shorter working hours was shown to have “massive benefits for people”, said Burchell, but he added: “If we move to a society where lots of people are completely excluded from the labour market, then I get very worried that's going to be a very dystopian future.”

;

;In his book Making Light Work: An End to Toil in the 21st Century, David Spencer, professor of economics at the University of Leeds, also makes the case for less work, but not its elimination. “It would leave us bereft potentially of things that we value in work,” he said, citing communal enterprise, personal relationships and the development of skillsets.

;

;So in essence, we would be a poorer, sadder, less skilled society. “Yes, there will be some loss through loss of work,” Spencer said. “I realise not all work is good. So we ought to automate drudgery, seek to use AI to reduce the pain of work, and therefore leave work which is good.”

;

;He draws from Morris, who talked about bringing joy to work. “Skilful work is good work and it has a role in the creation of a better society,” said Spencer. “We ought to use technology to create less and better work. In that sense, the future can be really positive.

;

;This was, he added, the future imagined by “Oscar Wilde, William Morris, and a lot of utopian positive thinking, where technology makes work lighter. It's not eliminating work – it's bringing light to work.”

; Sat, 04 Nov 2023 04:52:01 +0800 ‘It’s an abomination’: battle brewing over proposed US laws to protect pesticide companieshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/03/pesticide-regulation-cancer-bayer-roundup-law-legislation
;;2023-11-03T15:00:13Z;
;
;;Bottles of Monsanto's Roundup are seen for sale June 19, 2018 at a retail store in Glendale, California.
;

;Cancer patients are celebrating a string of courtroom victories after ;juries; in three US states recently ordered Germany's Bayer to pay more than $500m in damages for failing to warn about the health risks of its Roundup herbicides. But the consumer wins come as proposed federal legislation backed by Bayer and the powerful agricultural industry could limit similar cases from ever going to trial in the future.

;
;

;;Related: ;;US agency refuses to examine toxicity of 'inactive' pesticide chemicals to crops;

;
;

;Dubbed the ;Agricultural Labeling Uniformity Act;;,; the proposed measure would provide sweeping protections for pesticide companies and their products, pre-empting local governments from implementing restrictions on pesticide use and blocking many of the legal claims that have been plaguing Bayer, according to the American Association for Justice (AAJ) and other critics.

;

;The measure, which was introduced over the summer, has been gaining traction as a potential amendment to the pending Farm Bill. More than ;360 agricultural organizations; are throwing their support behind the measure, which was introduced by US representatives Dusty Johnson and Jim Costa. Lobbying disclosure records show that Bayer and the industry-funded ;CropLife America; have made passage of the measure a priority.

;

;The new law is needed because pesticides are “paramount to growing our food and keeping communities safe”, ;according to CropLife;.

;

;“Farmers and consumers need to not only be able to trust the regulation of the products they use but trust that the government has made decisions based on agreed-upon and established science, facts and data.”

;

;In response, on 27 October, more than 150 US lawmakers signed a letter to the leadership of the House committee on agriculture expressing “strong opposition” to the pre-emption measures, saying they would overturn “decades of precedent” and have a “significant impact” on public safety.

;

;Local laws that could be in jeopardy include many that restrict pesticide use near schools, parks and playgrounds, and protect drinking water supplies and wildlife. Pre-emption of state and local authority would additionally “limit accountability for manufacturers who fail to adequately warn consumers about the hazards posed by certain high-risk pesticides”, the letter warns.

;

;Senator Cory Booker called the legislation “reckless” and “irresponsible” in a press call on Thursday. “People are making this a priority in the upcoming Farm Bill, and frankly to me it is outrageous,” Booker said.

;

;Co-sponsor Johnson disputes the bill would have any “direct impact on any current or future litigation” or prevent local regulation of the “sale and use of pesticides”.

;

;Observers estimate the pre-emption amendment to the Farm Bill has a 50-50 chance of being added; a similar version is also under construction in the Senate.

;

;The industry efforts in Washington come as scores of cities and towns around the US have moved in recent years to limit or ban certain pesticides on public grounds due to evidence of health and environmental risks. Glyphosate, the active ingredient in Roundup weedkillers sold by Bayer, is among those being restricted.

;
;
;

;Parents and our city leaders, not the pesticide industry, should have the power to protect our children from hazardous pesticides in the parks where they play

;
; ;Kim Konte of Non-Toxic Neighborhoods;
;
;
;

;“Pre-emption is a threat to democracy and public health,” said Kim Konte, who leads Non-Toxic Neighborhoods, a grassroots organization that works with communities across the country to adopt pesticide-free practices. “Parents and our city leaders, not the pesticide industry, should have the power to protect our children from hazardous pesticides in the parks where they play.”

;

;Notably, the pre-emption efforts come as the Roundup litigation becomes ever more costly for Bayer, which bought the Roundup maker Monsanto in 2018. The company has already agreed to pay out billions of dollars in settlements to tens of thousands of people suffering from non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) they blame on exposure to Roundup and other Monsanto glyphosate-based herbicide brands.

;

;Additionally, the company has been ordered by multiple juries to pay hefty damage awards. Last month alone, juries ordered verdicts totaling ;$1.25m; in a Missouri case, ;$175m; in a Pennsylvania case and; $332m; in a California case.

;

;Jury selection begins later this month ;in a case; in San Benito, California, and several other trials are also on the dockets in multiple states. Among the central claims made in the nationwide litigation is that Monsanto's products should have carried warnings on their labels telling users of a cancer risk.

;

;Such claims would in effect be blocked, or substantially weakened, if the pre-emption measure becomes law, according to plaintiffs' lawyers and other experts. The measure would in effect make the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) the sole authority for determining when and if certain warnings should be required on labeled products.

;

;“It's an abomination,” said Brent Wisner, a member of the legal team that won the first Roundup case to go to trial. “I'm doing everything in my power to stop it.”

;

;Bayer is under pressure from investors to resolve the Roundup litigation and has argued in multiple courts that under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (Fifra), the EPA's stance that Monsanto's herbicides are not likely to cause cancer essentially bars complaints that Bayer and Monsanto failed to warn of a cancer risk.

;

;Courts have rejected the pre-emption argument because of a 2005 US supreme court ruling in a case titled Bates v Dow Agrosciences, which established that the EPA's approval of a product does not rule out claims brought under state laws. If the proposed bill is passed, it would undo the Bates precedent, according to the AAJ.

;

;Bayer did not answer a question about whether or not it initiated the legislation, but said in a statement that it supports the measure because “the future of American farming depends on reliable science-based regulation of important crop protection products that the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has determined safe for use”.

;

;Amid the legislative wrangling, cancer patient and Roundup plaintiff Larry Gainey said he did not want to see any pre-emption bill passed, and hoped for his own day in court.

;

;The 65-year-old South Carolina man used Monsanto herbicides for years working as a landscaper but was diagnosed with cancer in 2011 and continues to undergo treatments. He is too sick to work now, or “do much of anything”, Gainey said.

;

;“I just feel like, my gosh man, you go in a store and you buy a product and you think it's safe to use, and then if you come down with a severe illness you don't have a right to get some sort of compensation – it doesn't seem right to me.”

;
